723928f-a.title: Manhattan: Wall Street - William Street
723928f-a.text:
Wall Street, north side, west froc William Street (right), across Nassau Street (center), to Broadway (left margin). Shown is an early view of the financial district. The date of the view is determined by the absence of the Washington statue on the Sub Treasury steps (1883) and the presence of the massive National Bank of the Republic (1885) to the
right of Trinity Church.
Gift of Urbrock Collection

723927f-a.title: Manhattan: Wall Street - William Street

723919f-a.title: Manhattan: Wall Street - William Street
723919f-a.text:
Wall Street, west from William Street (foreground), to Broadway, showing on the west side of the latter, at the head of this thoroughfare, Trinity Church. This early view of the financial district is conspicious by the absence of the following institutions: The U. S. Trust Company of New York building of 1888 (No. 45-47); The heightened U. S. National Bank of New York building of 1890 (No. 41); The third (9 story) building of the Mechanics National Bank (No. 31-33); The VIilks Building at the S. W. corner of Wall and Broad Streets; The Gallatin National Bank bdilding of 1887 (in the process of construction at No. 34-36, adjoining the Assay Office) and the Bank of America
building of 1888-9 (No. 44-6).
Compare this view with one of 1895 and note the changes; the last of that period to go was the brownstone shown at the left; the site to this day (1938) being occupied by the same firm, the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company. An account of same was carried in a column titled
"Sky Lines' in the New York Sun of April 28, 1938.
Subsequently the following were replaced; the Drexel Morgan & Co. building in 1913; the old United States Assay Office building in 19i6; and the Mechanics National Bank building in 1932. 1929 saw the site for the present 7O storied Bank of Manhattan Building (No. 40) cleared. No. 2 of this set shows a view slightly later; the Gallatin National Bank Building being completed and with a workmens scaffold about to be removed. This structure was erected on a site which included their former building and a 1ot purchased from the dissolved Union Bank which was adjacent. The purchase price for the latter was ~d00000. The new nine story building was built and owned jointly by the Bank and Adrian Iselin.
723919f-a.folder: Wall Street & William Street, Manhattan, NY

This structure was erected on a site which included their former building and a 1ot purchased from the dissolved Union Bank which was adjacent. The purchase price for the latter was ~d00000. The new nine story building was built and owned jointly by the Bank and Adrian Iselin.

723920f-a.title: Manhattan: Wall Street - William Street
723920f-a.text:
Wall Street, west from 7iilliam Street, to Broadway, showing prominently the northerly side of this financial thoroughfare. Trinity Church, at the latter point dominates this locale. Preceding same to the right is the massive National ank of the Republic (Fort Sherman). To the left of the telegraph pole in the foreECround is the ornate Drexel Morgan S Co. Bldg. Cpposite are the entablatured U.S. Sub Treasury and Assay Office buildings. Adjacent to the last is the partially completed Gallatin National Bank Blag.
About 1887
Thru New York Historical Society
723920f-a.folder: Wall Street & William Street, Manhattan, NY

723925f-a.title: Manhattan: Wall Street - William Street
723925f-a.text:
Wall Street, at the N.W. corner of William Sgreet. Also shown is William Street, at and adjoining the N.W. corner of Wall Street.
The building concerned is the Bank of America.
Ahout 1890.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.

723934f-a.title: Manhattan: Wall Street - William Street
723934f-a.text:
Wall Street, north side, west from (No. 50, building at right) a point to the east of William Street and across same to Broadg8y (left, prinity Church seen on the north side of same). Fromddef6 t90ighpappear the Royal Insurance Building (No. 50); the Banlnr' New 909c (No. 48, building erected 1857); the Bank of America (No. 44-46, building erected 1888-1889); the Merchants National Bank (No. 40-42, erected 1884); a small 7 story structure, No. 38; the Gallatin National Bank (No. 36, erected 1887); the Assay office; the United States Sub treasury; the Gillenden Building; several others and finally the National Bank of the Republic (erected 1880).
About 1895.
Ewing Galloway

723921f-b.title: Manhattan: Wall Street - William Street
723921f-b.text:
(1)
Vall Street, west from William Street to Broadway and showing Trinity Church at that point. Note the changed aspects of this thoroughfare from an earlier view of 1890. (1.v.); buildings mentioned there in being here apparent. The prominent structure ocoupying the N.W. corner of Wall and Nassau Streets is the Gillenden Building which in 1911 will make way for the present f1938) Bankers Trust Company
Building.
June 1, 1904.
Brown Brothers.
(2)
A similar view emphasising the s)uth side of this thoroughfare. Note the Drexel, Morgan and the Wilks Buildings occupying opposite corners (S.E. and S.W. respeotively) of this and Broad Street.
June 1906.
George L. Bakgue.

723929f-a.title: Manhattan: Wall Street - William Street
723929f-a.text:
Wall Street, south side, east from William (right) to Hanover (left) Street's, showing the National City Bank. This structure was originally the Mrechants Exchange and later became the U. S. Custom House. It occhpies an entire sTuare, extending to Exchange Place.
About 1905
Gift of Urbrock Collection

723898f.title: Manhattan: Wall Street - William Street
723898f.text:
Wall Street, north side, west from (No. 34-36, right), a point midway between W illiam and Hassau Streets, across the latter to Broadway and he United  showing in a progressive order, the Gallatin National Bank; t States Assay Office: the United States Sub-Treasury; the BEiiEYELENGkt Co9Ne (59-sterdes); the Astor Building and the First National Bank. The Gallatin Bank apppearing on the right will be demolished in 1929 and its site will be included for the new 70-story Bank of Manhattan Building. Prior to that date the Assay Office was rebuilt to 4-stories.
1916.
0ift of Albert A. Volk Co.

723923f.title: Manhattan: Wall Street - William Street
723923f.text:
Wall Street, south side, west from Williar to Broad Streets, showing reapectively the 18-story Atlantic Building, No. 49-51; the 9-story U. S. Trust Co. Building, No. 45; the 25-story Equitable Trust Company Building, No. 37-43; a 10-story office structure and the 4-story J. P. Morgan and Company building, No. 23-33. Across the latter apoears the Wilks Building and a portion of the N. Y.
Stock Exchange.
About 1922
723923f.folder: Wall Street & William Street, Manhattan, NY

whep.oo. e.F5Wall Street at the N.E. corner of William Street. On this site will be erected the new National City Building, No. 52 Wall Street.

723924f-a.title: Manhattan: Wall Street - William Street
723924f-a.text:
Wall Street (center) at William Street (from left foreground to center), showing 4 coruuers of this intersection with building units at each. In the foreground is the National Uity Bank; to the left, the Atlantic Bldg.; in the center, the Bank of Amorica (adjoining same is the 7O storied Bank of Manhattan Building under corstruction7;and the Bank of New Yorl. Between the latter two apnears a glimpse of the Woolworth Tower. Note at the left, tne pyramid atop the Banlers Trust Co. Bldg. and
alao the Ecuitable Building.

Cotton Lxchange at Hanover Squuare.

723931f-a.title: Manhattan: Wall Street - William Street
723931f-a.text:
48-52 Wall Street, at and adjoining the N.E. corner of William Sereet. The building bearing ornament is the Bank of New York Building, (No. 48) and is directly at the afore said corner. Preceding same, is the National City Building (No. 52).  Prominently shown on the left, is the Ecuit ble Building (two units of 38-stories). The Woolworth Building appears on
the right.
About 1928.
Brown Brothers.
723931f-a.folder: Wall Street & William Street, Manhattan, NY

723930f-a.title: Manhattan: Wall Street - William Street
723930f-a.text:
wall Street, east from William Street to the East River. Note the subway station at the N.E. corner of this intersection and the South Ferry division of the Second and Third Aves. Elevated Lines on Pearl Street. The dark wall on the right is the northern side of the National
City Bank.
November 7, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
